Chapter 9: Close Attendance
Furthermore, Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who know gratitude and repay kindness cultivate great skillful means to benefit sentient beings, adapting to circumstances and displaying without bounds.
Good sons!

There was a Buddha who appeared in the world, called Abhaya-raja TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the Secular World, Unsurpassed Person, Tamer, Teacher of Gods and Men, Buddha, World-Honored One. He appeared in the world to guide those with karmic affinities.

After his nirvÄá¹‡a, in the true Dharma there was a brahmin's son who was intelligent and wise, upheld the five precepts, and protected the true Dharma.
The brÄhmaá¹‡a's son had gone on an errand to another country far away. On the way, there were many bandits and dangers. He was traveling with a group of five hundred people.
When they reached a dangerous road, at a place where they stopped, there were five hundred bandits who always stayed there, surrounding them before and after, wanting to rob the companions.
At that time, the leader of the bandits secretly sent a person to spy on the companions, and they were about to attack.
At that time, there was another person among the bandits who was a close friend of the brÄhmaá¹‡a's son. Because of their close friendship, he came first to warn him, saying:
Good man!
You should know that in the first watch of the night, there will be bandits attacking.
At that time, it will be chaotic and there is fear of injuring each other, so I have come to warn you.
You should secretly make a plan to leave far away, do not let your companions know.
At that time, when the brÄhmaá¹‡a's son heard these words, it was like a person choking, unable to swallow or spit out.

He wanted to tell his companions, but feared that his companions would kill this one person. If they killed this person, he feared that his companions would fall into the three evil paths and suffer immeasurable suffering.
If he remained silent, the thief would kill his companions. If he killed his companions, the thief would fall into the three evil paths and suffer immeasurable suffering.
Having thought this,
I shall devise a great expedient to benefit sentient beings, not for my own sake.
The suffering of the three evil paths is what I deserve.
Having contemplated this, he immediately took a knife and ended the thief's life, enabling his companions to be at ease and free from trouble.
At that time, the companions spoke with different mouths but the same voice, saying:
Son of the great Brahmin!
You are a superior person, and also a pure and good person. Why did you commit such a great evil today?
At that time, the son of the Brahmin knelt with his palms joined, feeling ashamed in his heart:
'But today I should not do evil, for the sake of the living beings and my companions.'
Then the companions said again:
'You yourself killed a man, what benefit is there to us?
' He replied to the people:
'This is a wicked thief who wanted to harm the companions.
For the sake of the companions, I cut off this person's life, so that the companions can return home safely.
And I will gladly accept the punishment in hell.'
Then the five hundred companions raised their voices and cried out, with sorrow and joy mixed together, saying:
'Nothing is more precious in the world than life, and nothing is more feared than death.

The reason for this is that all living beings give up gold, silver, precious treasures, countries, cities, wives, children, clothing, and food to save their lives. We and our companions are as if reborn.
Having said this, 'This Brahmin's son, for the sake of sentient beings, does not avoid the various sufferings and the retributions of the three evil destinies.
We should today think of his great kindness.
Repaying great kindness means we should now quickly give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.'
Having said this, they caused him to give rise to the mind [of enlightenment].
At that time the group of five hundred bandits said again:
'You are a superior person, a pure and good person, how could you commit such great evil?'
The Brahmin's son said:
'I truly know that I should not commit such great evil.
It is in order to benefit all sentient beings and to protect your bodies and lives.'
At that time the group of bandits said:
'You yourself kill people, what benefit is there to us?'
At that time the Brahmin's son replied to the bandits, saying:
'I knew you were here before, but I remained silent and did not inform the king or my companions.
For this reason, I have allowed you to remain safe and sound.'
When the thieves heard these words, they thought:
'Our lives have been given back to us.'
They then joined their palms together and faced the young man, saying:
'Excellent, great being!
Cultivator of great compassion!
Please command us what we should do.'
He replied:
'What I want done is for you to quickly give rise to the unsurpassed bodhi mind.'
At that time, the thieves, in order to repay their gratitude, immediately gave rise to the anuttara-samyak-sambodhi mind upon hearing this.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
The bodhisattva diligently seeks and makes progress, wishing to adorn bodhi and repay the Buddha's kindness. He should always remember all sentient beings as if they were his only child.
Good man!
You should know that the brÄhman's son at that time is none other thanğŸ”½
You should know that the brÄhmaá¹‡a's son at that time is none other than I myself.
It is because of this cause and condition that I surpassed nine kalpas and quickly attained supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Furthermore, the bodhisattva cultivates great skillful means and repays kindness with kindness.

The Buddha was staying at the Bamboo Grove monastery. There was a bhiká¹£u whose body suffered from a severe wound. Pus and blood constantly flowed all over his body. He was despised by the multitude and no one came close to him. He stayed in an old and dilapidated room on the outskirts.
At that time, the TathÄgata immediately manifested his spiritual powers, concealing the great assembly so that no one knew.
The TathÄgata went alone to where the sick bhiká¹£u was. According to his needs, he took water to wash him.
Having contemplated this, he caused all the devas in the desire realm to know.
Åšakra DevÄnÄm Indra, together with his retinue, surrounded by countless hundreds of thousands, rained down various celestial flowers, played various heavenly music, and stayed in the sky.

At that time, the Heavenly King of the Thirty-three Heavens held a hundred-blessed, wondrously adorned bathing vessel filled with pure, great compassion water, and immediately came forward to welcome [the Buddha], bowing his head at the TathÄgata's feet, then standing to one side.

At that time, the TathÄgata extended his hundred-blessed, adorned arm, and from his slender, long five fingers emitted a great light, illuminating the heavens and the great assembly that had gathered. The TathÄgata personally went to where the sick bhiká¹£u was and emitted a light from the top of his head, illuminating the sick bhiká¹£u.
When the bhiká¹£u encountered the light, his pain was immediately relieved. In the midst of the pus and blood, he arose, took refuge, and bowed his head, but his body did not follow.

The TathÄgata then used his right hand to receive the jeweled vessel from the Heavenly Emperor and poured it over the sick bhiká¹£u's head. With his left hand, he rubbed the sick bhiká¹£u's body. The sicknesses on his body were healed as soon as the TathÄgata's hand touched them.
After they were healed, he was overjoyed:
Homage to ÅšÄkyamuni!
Homage to the father of great compassion!
Homage to the unsurpassed, supreme king of physicians!
Although my physical illness has been cured today, I still have a mental illness.
The TathÄgata, out of compassion, now bestows the Dharma medicine upon me to cure the grave illnesses of both my body and mind.
At that time, the TathÄgata said to the sick bhiká¹£u:
The TathÄgata now remembers your great kindness;
the TathÄgata now wishes to repay your kindness.
At that time, the sick bhiká¹£u was overjoyed.
The Buddha then instructed, benefited, and delighted him. The bhiká¹£u was overjoyed and attained the fruit of arhatship, the three insights, the six higher knowledges, and the eight liberations.
Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra and his retinue, as well as innumerable devas, all fell into a net of doubt:
How could the TathÄgata stoop to wash the wounds, pus, and blood of a sick bhiká¹£u and say he is repaying kindness?
What is the matter? Please explain it to us.
The Buddha said to Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra and the great assembly of humans and devas:
Listen well!
I will explain to you about past events.
Åšakra, Lord of the Devas!
In the past, countless asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas ago, there was a king who was evil and tyrannical, oppressing others unjustly and seizing their wealth.
At that time, the evil king had a close confidant, a certain man of the five hundred, with whom he had a secret agreement:
'If there is anyone who commits an offense against the state, you should punish them severely, and I will reward you.
If you obtain any wealth, share it with me.'
At that time, the five hundred men always carried whips and canes. If someone obtained much wealth, they would be allowed to go free;
if someone had no wealth, they might lose their lives. This was their usual practice.
At that time, there was an upÄsaka who committed a minor offense against the state and was taken to the five hundred men, where he was to be whipped.
Hearing that this upÄsaka was a good and virtuous person, they allowed him to go free without being whipped, and he escaped from the danger.
For these causes and conditions, I am filled with immeasurable joy.
KauÅ›ika!
You should know that the five hundred people at that time are now the sick monks;

Therefore, the bodhisattva repays even a small kindness with a great one for immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, and his mind of right enlightenment is always undiminished.
At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, and immeasurable celestial multitudes were filled with immeasurable joy. Forty-eight thousand devas gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Having given rise to the mind of enlightenment, they made celestial music and each returned to their own abodes.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
If there are good sons and good women who know gratitude and repay kindness, they should practice four things:
First, to be close to good friends;
Second, to listen to the Dharma with utmost sincerity;
Third, to contemplate its meaning;
Fourth, to practice in accordance with the teachings.
There are also four dharmas:
First, following the Dharma, not the person;
Second, following the meaning, not the words;
Third, following wisdom, not consciousness;
Fourth, following the definitive meaning sutras, not the provisional meaning sutras.
Practicing these eight principles is called knowing gratitude.
Furthermore, practicing eight principles is called repaying gratitude.
What are the eight?
First, benefit;
Second, harm;
Third, slander;
Fourth, praise;
Fifth, fame;
Sixth, disrepute;
Seventh, suffering;
Eighth, happiness.

Furthermore, practicing four things is called knowing gratitude and also repaying gratitude:ğŸ”½First, seeing evil sentient beings, one gives rise to compassion because of cultivating the causes and conditions of kindness;
Second, seeing suffering sentient beings, one does not avert one's eyes for a moment because of giving rise to the causes and conditions of compassion;
Third, seeing teachers, parents, and virtuous people, the mind is joyful, giving rise to the causes and conditions of joy;
Fourth, seeing hateful sentient beings, the mind is not angry, cultivating the causes and conditions of equanimity.
At that time, Ä€nanda adjusted his robes, came forward, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
When the TathÄgata first gave rise to the mind of enlightenment, knowing kindness and repaying kindness, what is the meaning of practicing the first four things?
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

In the past, incalculably long eons ago, at that time there was a Buddha who appeared in the world, named VipaÅ›yin TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the Secular World, Unsurpassed Person, Tamer, Teacher of Gods and Men, Buddha, World-Honored One. He appeared in the world and guided those with affinities.
When those with affinities were finished, he passed away into nirvÄá¹‡a.
After the true Dharma and the semblance Dharma had disappeared, there was a country called Varanasi, where the people were prosperous and the land was fertile.
The king always governed the country with the right Dharma, not oppressing the people.
In that country there was a mountain called the Mountain of Sages.
On that mountain there were always five hundred pratyekabuddhas residing there, and many five-supernatural-powers immortals also lived there.
At that time there were many birds and beasts that came to rely on them.
There was a lion named Firm Vow, with golden-colored fur, who had great power and strength equal to a thousand, and when he let out a roar, flying birds fell down and running beasts hid.
Roaming in the mountains and marshes, he saw a pratyekabuddha bhiká¹£u with pure deportment.
Seeing him, he was delighted and became intimate with him day by day, always hearing him recite the sÅ«tras and expound the subtle Dharma.
At that time, there was a great hunter who saw the golden-haired lion and was overjoyed, thinking:
'If I can obtain this lion and skin it, and offer the skin to the king, he will surely bestow rank and emoluments, and I will be without want for seven generations.
' Having thought this, he further uttered these words:
'The lion with a firm vow, the king of beasts, cannot be reached by bow and arrow, and cannot be restrained by snares and nets.
I must now devise another plan.
What the lion with a firm vow respects and looks up to are the Å›ramaá¹‡as. I will now assume the appearance of a Å›ramaá¹‡a and secretly shoot it with a bow.
Covering myself with a kÄá¹£Äya robe, I will look down and walk slowly to the tree. If it sees me, it will surely come to be intimate.
Once it has become intimate, I will then pull the bowstring and shoot it with a poisoned arrow. There is no chance it will not be captured.'
Having thought this, he then returned home and proclaimed these words:
'From our ancestors down to now, we have always been hunters, and have never heard of an animal with golden fur, let alone seen one.
Now we want to hunt it down.'
So he shaved his beard and hair, put on Dharma robes, and as he had thought, returned to the mountains and sat under a tree.
At that time, the lion Firm Vow saw the bhiká¹£u, and with a joyful heart, he leaped up and licked the bhiká¹£u's feet.
At that time, the hunter immediately shot him.
Having been hit by a poisoned arrow, he growled and roared, wanting to pounce on him.
On the verge of destruction, he had this thought:
'This is a Å›ramaá¹‡a!
He wears the dyed robes, which are the banner of the sages of the three times.
If I were to harm him now, it would not be difficult, but if I were to take his life, I would be taking away the banner of the buddhas and sages.'
Having had this thought, he endured the pain and drank in the air.
After a short while, the poison spread further, and the pain became unbearable.
Having contemplated this, he again wanted to bite, and uttered these words:
This is not difficult.
If I were to harm him, I would be scolded by the Buddhas and sages.
Moreover, in the world, good and evil are not distinguished. This is an evil person who harbors poison and schemes to come and harm me;
if I do not endure, then I am no different from that evil person.
Those who cultivate patience are loved and respected by all;
those who do not endure are hated by the masses, and increase afflictions; because of increasing afflictions, birth and death increase;
because of increasing birth and death, one is born in difficult places;
because of being born in difficult places, one is far from good friends;
because of being far from good friends, one does not hear the right Dharma;
because of not hearing the Dharma, doubts and nets are heavily obscured;
because of the net of doubts, one is far from anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
Therefore, I should not give rise to evil thoughts now.
Having thought this, he then spoke a verse, saying:
I would rather lose my life than ever give rise to an evil mind
Toward those who have renounced the world and wear the dyed robes.ğŸ”½I would rather lose my life than ever give rise to an evil mind
Toward those who have left the household life.
Having spoken this verse, he immediately passed away.
The heavens and earth shook in six ways, startling the birds and beasts, which scattered in all directions;
Rain fell without clouds, and the sun lost its luster.
At that time, the hunter immediately took off his clothes, took his knife, skinned the deer, carried it on his back, and returned home.
Having arrived home, he presented it to the king.
The king, seeing it, was delighted and asked his ministers, saying:
Since my birth, I have never heard of an animal with golden-colored body hair. How is it that I have now seen it with my own eyes today?ğŸ”½How strange!
How unusual!
He slowly asked the hunter:
'What expedient means did you use to obtain this skin?'
At that time, the hunter stepped forward and said to the king:
'I only wish that the great king would grant me fearlessness, and I will tell the great king about the above matter.'
The king said:
'As you wish!'
At that time, the hunter fully told the above matter to the great king.
When the king heard these words, he was filled with sorrow, like a person who is choked and cannot swallow or spit out.
He then issued a proclamation, and when all the great ministers, minor kings, and the great assembly had gathered, he himself proclaimed:
'All of you!
You should know that I have heard such words from the wise:
If there are animals with golden-colored body hair, they must be bodhisattvas.
If a single sentient being arouses the bodhi mind, it will bring great benefits to all sentient beings.
How is it that today this evil hunter has devised a means to kill this bodhisattva?

If I were now to bestow official ranks, salaries, elephants, horses, the seven treasures, clothing, food and drink, money, grain, silk, and other things on this evil person, then I would be on the same path as him, becoming his companion in toil.'
Having contemplated this, he immediately took the hunter's life.

He took the lion's skin and returned to the mountains, to the place where the corpse was. He then gathered ox-head sandalwood to make a pyre, cremated the lion's skin and bones with fire, collected the relics, and built a stupa to make offerings.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
Good men!
The lion with firm vows is now I, ÅšÄkyamuni.
The bodhisattva is like this, closely following good friends, even to the point of losing his life, he never gives rise to evil.
Why is this?
It is because he knows kindness and repays kindness.
Why is this?
Because the bodhisattva, by being able to closely follow good and virtuous friends, is able to quickly accomplish supreme perfect enlightenment.
Good man!

Bodhisattvas always diligently seek good and wise advisors, in order to hear the Buddha's teachings, even a single sentence, a single verse, or a single meaning. The afflictions of the three realms all wither away.

When bodhisattvas wholeheartedly seek the Buddha's words, their thirst for the Dharma is intense, and they do not value their bodies or lives. Even if they tread on burning iron and fierce flames, they do not consider it a hardship.
For the sake of a single verse, bodhisattvas would not even begrudge their lives, let alone the twelve divisions of the scriptures?
For the sake of a single verse, they would not even begrudge their bodies and lives, let alone other wealth and possessions?
Because of the benefits of hearing the Dharma, the body attains peace and joy, and deeply gives rise to faith and a sincere and correct view.
Seeing those who expound the Dharma is like seeing one's parents, and the mind is free from arrogance.
For the sake of sentient beings, one listens to the Dharma with a sincere mind, not for personal gain;
for the sake of sentient beings, not for one's own benefit;
For the sake of the true Dharma, they are not afraid of the difficulties of kings, hunger and thirst, cold and heat, tigers, wolves, and vicious beasts, robbers and thieves, etc.
First, they tame their own afflictions and faculties, and then listen to the Dharma, not listening at inappropriate times.
They listen to the Dharma with utmost sincerity, respect the expounder, and revere the Dharma. This is called the bodhisattva's knowledge of gratitude and repaying kindness.
How do bodhisattvas listen to the Dharma with utmost sincerity?
Listening to the Dharma has four aspects:
First, utmost sincerity;
Second, single-mindedness;
Third, wholeheartedness;
Fourth, wholesome mind.
This is called the bodhisattva's diligent seeking of the twelve divisions of the scriptures.
Why is it so?

Thinking of the Buddha's heavy kindness, in order to spread the true Dharma of the Buddhas, in order to increase the Buddhadharma, in order to cause the world to believe in the Buddha's Dharma, in order to cause all immeasurable sentient beings to attain the supreme path of bodhi, therefore the Bodhisattva thinks of the immeasurable sentient beings of the ten directions, in order to repay the Buddhas' heavy kindness, therefore the Bodhisattva diligently seeks the twelve divisions of the canon.
Why does the Bodhisattva diligently seek the Buddha's teachings?
In order to cause sentient beings to give rise to faith, therefore he seeks the treatises on causes;

In order to know all faults and offenses, in order to destroy the evil and heterodox teachings of non-Buddhists, in order to know the skillful means of taming sentient beings, in order to distinguish the meaning of the TathÄgata's words and the meaning of worldly words, therefore the Bodhisattva seeks the treatises on causes.
Why does the Bodhisattva seek the treatises on sound?
In order to make his speech pure and adorned, because impure speech cannot clearly proclaim the definitive meaning;
In order to understand all meanings;
Not to destroy right speech, due to a mind of arrogance;
To destroy wrong views, in order to know the skillful means to tame sentient beings, therefore the Bodhisattva seeks out the science of sound.
Why does the Bodhisattva seek out medical prescriptions?

In order to cause sentient beings to be free from the four hundred and four illnesses of evil and unwholesomeness, out of compassion for all sentient beings, in order to cause them to give rise to faith;
Having already become free from illness, the mind gives rise to joy;
Having attained joy, the mind always thinks of the Buddhas' great compassion, in order to liberate sentient beings, therefore the Bodhisattva seeks out medical prescriptions.
Why does the Bodhisattva seek out worldly techniques?
In order to easily obtain wealth and benefit sentient beings;
In order to cause sentient beings to give rise to faith;
In order to know worldly affairs and destroy arrogance;
In order to tame sentient beings;
In order to know all dharmas and tame the obstructions of darkness.
If there are bodhisattvas who are unable to seek these five things in this way, they will never be able to attain supreme, perfect enlightenment and accomplish omniscience.
In order to attain supreme enlightenment, they seek these five things.
Bodhisattvas who know gratitude and repay kindness expound for sentient beings.
What do they expound?
How do they expound?
What they expound are the twelve divisions of the scriptures;
How they expound is by accomplishing five things, in order to attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
There are two things in expounding:
First, expounding in sequence;
Second, expounding in a pure manner.
Expounding in sequence means:
First expounding the perfection of giving, then expounding the perfection of morality up to the perfection of wisdom.
In order to know gratitude and repay kindness, one contemplates its meaning and abides in accordance with the Dharma. This is called expounding in sequence.
Expounding in a pure manner means:
If the listener is sitting and the expounder is standing, one should not expound for them;
If the listener seeks faults in the Dharma or seeks faults in the speaker, one should not speak for them;
If the listener relies on the person but not on the Dharma, or does not rely on the Dharma, one should not speak for them;
If the listener relies on the words but not on the meaning, one should not speak for them;
Up to if the listener does not rely on the definitive sÅ«tras, one should not speak for them.
Why is this?
Because such people cannot respectfully revere the pure Dharma of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas.

If the Dharma speaker reveres the Dharma, and the Dharma listener also gives rise to respect and listens with a sincere mind without giving rise to contempt, this is called the pure speaking of the Dharma.
The gradual speaker speaks everything.
The speaker of everything refers to the twelve divisions of the scriptures, up to a single sentence, a single verse, up to half a verse.
When demonstrating, teaching, benefiting, and delighting in the Dharma and meaning, at times reprimanding, at times speaking truthfully, at times speaking in analogy, speaking as appropriate;

Or, if it is taught in a shallow and easy way, or in a way that is easy to enter, according to what is joyfully heard, this is called the bodhisattva's teaching of the Dharma in sequence, knowing kindness and repaying kindness.
As for pure teaching, bodhisattva mahÄsattvas cultivate a mind of loving-kindness towards enemies and those they dislike.

Having attained a mind of loving-kindness, they use various skillful means to teach the Dharma to evil beings and negligent people, and even to those who are greedy, arrogant, and poor, they skillfully reveal and teach the Dharma for them. It is not for the sake of praising oneself, denigrating others, food and drink, material gain, or fame, this is called the bodhisattva's pure teaching of the Dharma, knowing kindness and repaying kindness.
What is it to abide in accordance with the Dharma?
Cultivating wholesome dharmas with body, speech, and mind, being replete with purity, knowing kindness and repaying kindness, in order to adorn anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
Furthermore, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas know gratitude and repay kindness. Contemplating its meaning, they become learned and attain dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, blazing the torch of the Dharma.
For the benefit of all sentient beings, they should cultivate giving, precepts, and learning.
Making offerings to the expounder, not seeking faults in the Dharma or the expounder, having no harmful thoughts, and bestowing fearlessness upon sentient beings - this is called knowing gratitude.
Enjoying the bliss of humans and gods and attaining the bliss of the path and nirvÄá¹‡a - this is called repaying kindness.
Bodhisattvas have four kinds of cultivation of patience, which destroy impatience, adorn enlightenment, and gather in sentient beings.
Causing them to cultivate patience, whether enduring themselves or causing others to endure, and being free from fear - this is called knowing gratitude.
Due to the causes of patience, there is no angry mind, the retinue is not destroyed, one does not experience suffering or distress, and the mind is free from regret;
Having abandoned this body, one experiences the bliss of humans and gods and quickly attains the bliss of nirvÄá¹‡a - this is called repaying kindness.
Good sons!
Bodhisattvas have four things that diligently cultivate diligence, destroy laziness, adorn enlightenment, and embrace sentient beings.
For the sake of the path of enlightenment, they cause the cultivation of diligence;
Sleeping peacefully and waking peacefully, free from afflictions;
Increasing wholesome dharmas, the body experiences blissful happiness, this is called benefiting oneself.
The bodhisattva's diligence does not afflict sentient beings, beating and scolding, this is called benefiting others.

After abandoning this body, one receives the bliss of humans and gods, the body obtains great strength, and attains the path of enlightenment, this is called great fruit, this is called the bodhisattva's four things of diligence.
Bodhisattvas cultivate concentration, destroy the confused mind, adorn enlightenment, and embrace sentient beings.
For the sake of the path of enlightenment, they cause the cultivation of meditation, presently receiving worldly bliss, the body and mind are tranquil, this is called knowing gratitude.
Because the body and mind are tranquil, they do not afflict sentient beings, this is called repaying gratitude.
After the bodhisattva abandons this body, he receives a pure body, peaceful and blissful, and attains great nirvÄá¹‡a. This is called the four matters of the bodhisattva's meditation.
Furthermore, the bodhisattva knows gratitude and repays kindness, accomplishes wisdom, destroys ignorance, adorns enlightenment, and embraces sentient beings with the four means of conversion.
For the sake of the path of enlightenment, he cultivates wisdom. Because he knows the Dharma realm, he receives the bliss of the body. This is called benefiting oneself.
He is able to give rise to worldly and supramundane matters for sentient beings. This is called benefiting others.
He is able to destroy the two hindrances of afflictions and wisdom. This is called the great fruit. This is called knowing gratitude. This is called repaying kindness.
The four matters of the bodhisattva's wisdom are inconceivable.
Furthermore, the bodhisattva, without the knowledge of past lives, knows the matters of past existences, in order to observe the good and evil karma of sentient beings who experience the same good.
In order to benefit all sentient beings, the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva, with great skillful means, abides in Tuá¹£ita Heaven, accomplishing a lifespan, with three things surpassing:
First, surpassing in lifespan;
Second, surpassing in appearance;
Third, surpassing in fame.
When first descending, he emits a great light, illuminating the ten directions;
He himself knows when he first enters his mother's womb, when he abides there, and when he emerges;
When he walks seven steps in the ten directions, without anyone supporting him, he says:
This body of mine is the final limit.
Devas, ghosts, gandharvas, asuras, garuá¸as, kiá¹ƒnaras, and mahoragas make offerings with various flowers, incense, subtle music, and banners and canopies;
His body is adorned with the thirty-two marks, and there is no one who can surpass him;
With the power of kind and wholesome deeds, he destroys the armies of MÄra;
Each joint and limb possesses the great strength of NÄrÄyaá¹‡a;
In the years of youth, without learning worldly matters, he is able to know them;
Without a teacher, he learns on his own and naturally attains supreme, perfect enlightenment;
BrahmÄ Heaven entreats him to turn the wheel of the true Dharma for the sake of all sentient beings;
Properly receiving samÄdhi, the sound of thunder cannot make him move;
